content: I've been developing small command-line applications with Python and now I want to start developing GUIs. I'm inclined towards using wxPython and Tkinter. Can you recommend any good IDEs for these toolkits that also have a GUI designer? I'd prefer not to code all of the GUI myself. I'm open to both free and paid options.

Certainly! Transitioning from command-line applications to GUI development is an exciting step, and both wxPython and Tkinter are great choices for building desktop applications with Python. Here are some IDEs and tools that can assist you in designing GUIs with these toolkits:

### For wxPython:

1. **wxFormBuilder**
   - **Description**: A powerful, free, and open-source GUI designer specifically for wxPython. It allows you to design your interface visually and generate the corresponding Python code.
   - **Website**: [wxFormBuilder](https://github.com/wxFormBuilder/wxFormBuilder)

2. **wxGlade**
   - **Description**: Another free and open-source GUI designer for wxPython. It supports the design of complex interfaces and generates Python code.
   - **Website**: [wxGlade](http://wxglade.sourceforge.net/)

### For Tkinter:

1. **PAGE (Python Automatic GUI Generator)**
   - **Description**: PAGE is a drag-and-drop GUI generator specifically for Tkinter. It is a free tool that lets you design your GUI and produce Python code.
   - **Website**: [PAGE](http://page.sourceforge.net/)

2. **Tkinter Designer**
   - **Description**: Tkinter Designer is a modern tool that uses Figma designs to create Tkinter GUIs. It’s ideal if you prefer a more visual design approach.
   - **Website**: [Tkinter Designer](https://github.com/ParthJadhav/Tkinter-Designer)

### General IDEs with GUI Design Support:

1. **PyCharm Professional**
   - **Description**: PyCharm is a popular Python IDE that provides support for various frameworks and has a robust feature set. The Professional version includes support for GUI design and integration with tools like PyQt Designer.
   - **Website**: [PyCharm](https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/)

2. **Visual Studio**
   - **Description**: Visual Studio (not to be confused with Visual Studio Code) is a comprehensive IDE that offers Python support through extensions and has built-in GUI design tools for various languages and frameworks.
   - **Website**: [Visual Studio](https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/)

3. **Eclipse with PyDev and WindowBuilder**
   - **Description**: Eclipse is a versatile IDE that can be configured for Python development with PyDev. WindowBuilder is an Eclipse plugin that provides a GUI designer.
   - **Website**: [Eclipse](https://www.eclipse.org/)

Each of these tools has its strengths, so you might want to try a few to see which one fits your workflow best. If you're new to GUI design, starting with a tool that offers drag-and-drop functionality can significantly speed up your development process.
